section.title: Contact Information
section.p: To reach me or PCC:
Because of federal privacy laws, all email communications related to this class need to be sent to and from your @pcc.edu email address.
I have drop-in office hours where you do not need to make an appointmentjust come by!

Come visit me for help with the material, help with homework, or questions about your grade. If those times are not workable for you, please feel comfortable contacting me to make some other arrangements.
While I do have an office phone number and voice mail, I am more likely to reply to you more quickly if you use email to contact me.

section.title: Course Description
section.p: Taken from the official PCC course description:

Introduces algebraic concepts and processes with a focus on linear equations, linear inequalities, and systems of linear equations. Emphasizes number-sense, applications, graphs, formulas, and proper mathematical notation. Prerequisites: MTH 20 and (RD 80 or ESOL 250) or equivalent placement. Recommended: MTH 20 be taken within the past 4 terms. The PCC math department recommends that students take MTH courses in consecutive terms. Audit available.
The complete Course Content and Outcome Guide can be found at www.pcc.edu/ccog/.

section.title: Prerequisite Review
section.p: These exercises use skills from MTH 20, and in MTH 60 there is some assumption that students can do these tasks. If you find that you are rusty with any of these topics, please come to my office or the student learning center and we can refresh you on how these all work.

solution.p: a.
b.
In multiplication, each pair of negative signs cancel. If all negative signs are canceled, the product is positive; if there is one negative sign left, the product is negative.
a.
b.
The rules for dividing positive numbers are the same as those for multiplication:
\displaystyle{ \text{positive} \div \text{positive} = \text{positive} },
\displaystyle{ \text{positive} \div \text{negative} = \text{negative} },
\displaystyle{ \text{negative} \div \text{positive} = \text{negative} },
\displaystyle{ \text{negative} \div \text{negative} = \text{positive} }.

To add two fractions with different denominators, we first have to find a common denominator.
In this case, the least common multiple of 7 and 28 is 28.
Look at the first fraction \displaystyle{-\frac{4}{7}}. To change the denominator to 28, we multiply 4 at both the top and bottom, and we have:
The second fraction already has the common denominator.
Finally, we can do the addition. The full process is:
To add or subtract two fractions with different denominators, we first have to find the common denominator.
In this case, the least common multiple of 6 and 18 is 18.
Look at the first fraction \displaystyle{-\frac{1}{6}}. To change the denominator to 18, we multiply 3 at both the top and bottom, and we have:
Since the second fractions denominator is the same as the common denominator, there is no need to make changes to the second fraction.
Finally, we add or subtract the numerators and keep the common denominator unchanged. The whole process is:
We must follow the order of operations when simplifying this expression. Begin by doing the division.
According to the order of operations, the multiplication has higher priority than the addition.
You might need to go back to previous units to review how to add fractions.
You might need to go back to previous units to review how to add fractions.

li.p: The absolute value of 3 measures how many units are between 3 and 0 on the number line, so |{3}|=3.
The absolute value of -3 measures how many units are between -3 and 0 on the number line, so |{-3}|=3.
The absolute value symbols cannot affect what are outside them, so we have -|{3}|=-3.
Similar to Part c, we have -|{-3}|=-3.

statement.p: Write the following percentages as decimals.

solution.p: To change a percentage to a decimal, we move the decimal to the left twice.

statement.p: Write the following decimals as percentages.

solution.p: To change a decimal to a percentage, we move the decimal point to the right twice.

statement.p: Write the following decimals as percentages.

solution.p: To change a decimal to a percentage, we move the decimal point to the right twice.

statement.p: Kandace is paying a dinner bill of {\$47.00}. Kandace plans to pay 12\% in tips. How much tip will Kandace pay?

solution.p: This problem can be boiled down to this question: What is 12\% of 47? We will show multiple methods to solve this problem.
Method 1
We will use proportion to solve this problem. Assume 12\% of 47 is x, so 12 out of 100 corresponds to x out of 47.
We will write and solve the proportion:
Kandace will pay {\$5.64} in tip.
Method 2
We will use the percentage formula to solve this problem. This translation from English to math may help you remember the percentage formula.
The question is: What is 12\% of 47? Assume x is 12\% of 47. We have:
Kandace will pay {\$5.64} in tip.
Method 3
In the sentence What is 12\% of 47,

li.p: what is the percentage,
12\% is the rate,
47 is the base (following the word of).

solution.p: By the formula \text{percentage} = \text{rate} \cdot \text{base}, we do a multiplication to solve the problem:
Kandace will pay {\$5.64} in tip.

statement.p: In the past few seasons basketball games, Connor attempted 440 free throws, and made 396 of them. What percent of free throws did Connor make?
Connor made of free throws in the past few seasons.

solution.p: This problem can be boiled down to this question: 396 is what percent of 440? We will show multiple methods to solve this problem.
Method 1
We will use proportion to solve this problem.
Assume 396 is x\% of 440, so x out of 100 corresponds to 396 out of 440.
We will write and solve the proportion:
Connor made 90\% of free throws in the past few seasons.
Method 2
We will use the percentage formula to solve this problem.
This translation from English to may should help you remember the percentage formula.
Assume 396 is x (as a percent) of 440. We have:
Connor made 90\% of free throws in the past few seasons.
Method 3
In the sentence 396 is what percent of 440,

li.p: 396 is the percentage,
what percent is the rate,
440 is the base (following the word of).

solution.p: By the formula \text{rate} = \frac{\text{percentage}}{\text{base}}, we do a division to solve the problem:
Connor made 90\% of free throws in the past few seasons.
Since there is no operation symbol between 6 and (2), it implies multiplication.
We perform multiplication first, as multiplication has a higher priority than addition.
Since there is no operation symbol between 2 and (2+2), it implies multiplication.
We need to perform operations inside the parentheses first, as parentheses have a higher priority than multiplication.
In the order of operations, parentheses take priority above exponents.
The bracket [ ] and parentheses ( ) have the same purpose. We usually use [ ] when ( ) are already used in the problem, so we can tell which pair are which.

section.title: Expectations
section.p:
MTH 60 can be a challenging course, so the main expectation is that you commit to the course with the goal of passing with an A, and play an active role in your learning. We will be using the flipped classroom model. For each day of class:
You will watch videos before coming to class.
You will take notes on the videos and turn them in at the start of class.
You will answer some reading questions from the textbook and turn them in at the start of class.
In class we will work together in groups practicing what you learned.
You have some online homework to complete within five or six days of the in-class practice.
Occasionally, there will be pencil-and-paper homework to turn in as well.
There is evidence that the flipped model can raises the pass rates in math courses by a lot! More traditional methods for running a class have lately led to a 60% pass rate in MTH 60. Flipping could raise this, and those who pass are more likely to pass with an A.

Additionally, please:
Try to complete all homework assignments earlier than the due date. Begin working on homework assignments the same day that we discuss that material in class.
Make time to visit me in office hours.

The ideas are covered in a natural sequence, and if you stay on top of the assignments, you have a high chance for success. All students are further encouraged to work togethercollaboration is an important part of any activity, and it is almost always beneficial for all involved.

Here are some other expectations:
Maintain respect for yourself and your classmates.
Do not use phones, tablets, or computers during class time unless it is directly related to a class activity.
Check your @pcc.edu email at least once a day.
Food and drink can be distracting to other students. Out of respect for others, please do not bring food and drink to class. (Beverages that do not smell strongly and are in spill-proof containers are OK.)

section.title: Technology Requirements
section.p: In regular class time, a smart phone, tablet, or laptop is fine. During an exam, you must have a scientific calculator and you may not use other devices that connect to the internet. If you do not own one, there are options for you to borrow one.
You will also need Internet access for most of your homework. If you do not have Internet access at home, you can find it in PCC computer labs.

section.title: Textbook
section.p: We are using a new free textbook written by PCC faculty. The book is called ORCCA (Open Resources for Community College Algebra). We're excited to replace a roughly $117 book with this free book and save you money.
If you find any issues with this book where you think we could make it better, please let me know about each one.

Access this book:
as a free eBook at spot.pcc.edu/math/orcca/ed2/html.
as a (color or black-and-white) PDF for download at spot.pcc.edu/math/orcca/ed2/pdf.
for purchase from the PCC book store for $15.40.
for purchase from Amazon (amzn.to/33neZdk) for $15.40.

introduction.p: General PCC Grading Guidelines are found at catalog.pcc.edu/handbook/g301-gradingguidelines.

paragraphs.title: Class Prep Assignments
paragraphs.p:
Most class days you are supposed to come to class with a class prep assignment completed.
You watched the videos and took notes.
You answered the reading questions.
You'll turn these in when you come into class. Later while you work on some practice exercises, I will look over your prep assignments and give you credit for them. I'll return them to you and ask you if you have questions about the topics.
If you arrive to class and you haven't done the prep assignment, I will ask you to leave and complete it before coming back to class.
Each prep assignment is worth 0.5% of your grade. There are 19 of these total, so all together they are worth 9.5% of your grade.
If you miss class, you may scan/photo your work and send it to me electronically before the end of the day it is due.

paragraphs.title: In-class Group Work
paragraphs.p: Most class days, you will work in small groups on a collection of exercises that go along with the lesson you prepared for. If you work on these diligently during class time with your partners, you will get credit for 0.5% of your final grade for each one (even if your group is not able to finish these in time). There are 19 of these, so in total these are worth 9.5% of your grade.

If you miss class, you may bring a fully completed activity to me within one week and still get the 0.5% credit. The online syllabus will have the exercise packets from each day for you to download using the . Turning these in late, they must be fully completed, not partially completed. The work must be shown, not just the answers.

paragraphs.title: Online Homework
paragraphs.p: You have online homework for each section using . See for details. The due date for each assignment is posted in . Generally when a topic is on our course calendar, the online homework is due five or six days later. You should start working on it soon after the class that works on that topic, ideally on the same day.
Collectively, all the online homework is worth 10% of your final grade.

paragraphs.title: Written Assignments
paragraphs.p: In the latter half of the course, your homework includes some exercises where you must write up something on paper. Turn these in on the days they are due. Each written assignment is worth 1% of your grade for a total of 6%. See for the specifics.

paragraphs.title: Exams
paragraphs.p: Please refer to the for exam dates, and for details about what is covered on each exam. Exams 1, 2, and 3 are each worth 20%, 20%, and 25%, of your grade.

section.title: WeBWorK Assignments
section.p: I have made an account for you on a program called at webwork.pcc.edu/webwork2/mth060-jordan-201904. Each week there are problem sets and you are required to answer them online using . The topics that we cover in a week have exercises that are typically due in the middle of the following week at 10:00 on the night in between the days we meet, but can be worked on much earlier. You may submit answers any time before the due date. You may work from home or use PCC computer labs to turn in your answers.
Here is an example of what a problem is like.

statement.p: Use the properties of exponents to simplify .

solution.p: We add the exponents as follows: \amp=x^{+}\amp=x^{}

statement.p: Use the properties of exponents to simplify {x^{4}x^{3}}\text{.}

solution.p: We add the exponents as follows:

paragraphs.title: Why are we using WeBWorK?
paragraphs.p: Traditionally, homework comes from textbook problems that students would do on paper, and then turn in in to the instructor. One drawback of this is that students get no feedback at all until about a week later, and at that point the student is no longer actively thinking about material from two weeks earlier. Another drawback is that it is impossible for a student to do the appropriate amount of homework and for the instructor to give quality feedback for every single exercise. Often an instructor is only able to give feedback for a small subset of the exercises. Using brings the following advantages over traditional homework.

li.title: Cost
li.p: is free, unlike many online homework programs.

li.title: Timely Feedback
li.p: Rather than waiting a week for written feedback from your instructor, you get instant feedback from .

li.title: Quality Feedback
li.p: will do more than just tell you if you are right or wrong. For example, it will usually tell you if you haven't completely simplified an answer or forgot to include units when they are required. Sometimes it will do even more. Try entering x^12 as the answer to .

li.title: Ease of Communication
li.p: encourages you to write your instructor for help, who can provide even higher quality feedback based on your message and your previous attempts.

li.title: Multiple or Unlimited Attempts
li.p: On paper, when you submit an answer, that's the end of it. With you might get a problem wrong on your first attempt, but you are encouraged to figure out your mistakes and try again.

li.title: Efficient Use of Class Time
li.p: Your instructor can monitor the whole class and see in real-time which problems and concepts are causing the class difficulty.

li.title: Extra Practice
li.p: Your instructor can set things up so that you can retry each problem with new random numbers involved. If you are unsure if you have mastered a skill, this gives you a way to keep practicing.

paragraphs.title: Logging in to WeBWorK
paragraphs.p: Go directly to webwork.pcc.edu/webwork2/mth060-jordan-201904. If you are working at your own computer, you might want to bookmark this link. Your username is your PCC email prefix, using all lowercase letters. For example, mine is alex.jordan because my email address is alex.jordan@pcc.edu. Your initial password is your PCC G-number, using a capital G.

paragraphs.title: The First Time You Log On
paragraphs.p: You should go to the User Settings menu in the upper left and change your password. There is an Orientation assignment for you to take. Click on the Orientation, and begin by reading the paragraph to the right that says Read This First. Take the time to complete the Orientation, and you will understand a lot about how behaves. The Orientation will remain available to you for the entire term, so you can always come back and look at it again.

paragraphs.title: Homework Sets Menu
paragraphs.p:
This shows you the assignments that have been assigned to you and when they are due. You may:
click on an assignment and begin working on problems online
check the box next to an assignment and click Download Hardcopy to get the assignment as a .pdf file which you may then print to work on away from a computer.

When you click on an assignment, you will see a screen with the problem numbers listed. Off to the right is a message for you that might have specific instructions or information about the assignment. You should always look for and read this message.

paragraphs.title: Emailing for Help
paragraphs.p: When you are stumped, you can click the Email Instructor button at the bottom of any problem. Write a message explaining what you have tried and if possible, include the work from your calculations. will send your instructor an email with helpful information (like all of the incorrect attempts you have tried) and they get back to you soon with a response. When they respond, it will be with an email, so you must remember to check your email.

paragraphs.title: Math Achievements
paragraphs.p: As you complete more problems through the term, you will win badges for various achievements. For example, the On One Hand badge is for completing a homework set with fewer than five incorrect submissions. Both earning badges and just plain answering questions correctly will earn you achievement points. As you gain more achievement points, you will level up. Each time you level up, you earn an item that can be used to affect your grade.

li.title: Level 1: Lesser Rod of Revelation
li.p: Give yourself 50% credit on one problem.

li.title: Level 2: Potion of Forgetfulness
li.p: Drop the number incorrect attempts down to 0.

li.title: Level 3: Tunic of Extension
li.p: Extend the due date of a currently open homework for 24 hours.

li.title: Level 4: Cupcake of Enlargement
li.p: Double the weight of one problem.

li.title: Level 5: Box of Transmogrification
li.p: Change a single problem to be a (newly randomized) copy of a different problem on the same homework set.

li.title: Level 6: Greater Rod of Revelation
li.p: Give yourself 100% credit on one problem.

li.title: Level 7: Robe of Longevity
li.p: Extend the due date of a currently open homework for 48 hours.

li.title: Level 8: Scroll of Resurrection
li.p: Reopen a homework set (even a closed one) for an additional 24 hours. All problems will be re-randomized.

li.title: Level 9: Greater Tome of Enlightenment
li.p: Earn 100% on every problem in a single homework set.

li.title: Level 10: Cake of Enlargement
li.p: Double the weight of an entire set.

section.title: Written Assignments
section.p: These must be turned in no later than their posted due dates. These are where you will get to show me your mathematical writing and graphing skills.

The most important thing to understand about your written homework is that you are not merely finding and giving answers. You are explaining to someone what the problem was, how you handled it, and summarizing the results. In general, your write-ups should respect these five C's:
Clarity
Am I able to read your work? Is your writing legible? Have you written complete sentences that make sense, where appropriate? If you have charts, graphs, and mathematical expressions, have you clearly indicated what they represent? Generally, any graphs need their axes labeled with regularly spaced tick marks, and they need some kind of overall title. If something about your write-up causes me to pause and wonder what you mean, you will lose clarity points.
Correctness
Are your numerical answers and conclusions accurate? Often you can check that your numbers are correct by substituting numbers back into earlier equations. Also, by asking yourself if the numbers that you find make sense in the context of the problem. It's not a bad idea to include these checks with your work.
Conciseness
Have you rambled on with extra content that is not relevant to solving the problem? This is distracting and hurts the overall ability of your write-up to communicate effectively.
self-Containment
The response to the question that you submit should make it clear what the original question was. Put yourself in the shoes of another student from the class who does not have the original homework assignment in front of them. Would they be able to understand what you are talking about? At a minimum, this means that you must give an introduction of some kind that lets your reader know what you are about to investigate. Also, include any and all charts, graphs, and mathematical expressions that were given in the problem, and explain their meaning, even if you do so merely with labels.
Conclusions
Some problems come with context (word problems). When writing your final answer to such a question, you need to put that answer in its full context with a conclusion statement that is a complete English sentence. As an example, writing x=70 or He needs $70 will not be good enough if there is more context to the problem. Instead, something like Dmitri needs $70 in order to purchase a new lawnmower is a conclusion statement with all of the context in it. For problems without context, conclusion statements like The solution set is \{70\}. are acceptable.

introduction.p: Please see the for the exam dates.
About a week before each exam, you will receive a practice exam. Practice exams are typically longer than the real exam to give you more to practice with.

li.title: Exam 1 (20%)
li.p: Covers sections 1.11.8.
You'll have the entire class period for this exam if you need it.

li.title: Exam 2 (20%)
li.p: Covers sections 2.13.5. Additionally there will be some repeated questions from Exam 1. (So part of your studying should be reviewing your first exam.)
You'll have the entire class period for this exam if you need it.

li.title: Exam 3 (25%)
li.p: Covers sections 3.63.8 and 4.14.3. Additionally there will be some repeated questions from Exams 1 and 2. (So part of your studying should be reviewing your first and second exams.)
This exam is during finals week and is only two hours long.

paragraphs.title: Missing an Exam
paragraphs.p: If you miss an exam, you must contact me within one day to explain why or I might not be able to allow a make-up and you would receive a zero. Make-up exams are only permitted under extreme circumstances. PCC does not have enough staff and facilities to administer too many make-up exams. If you have a valid excuse, you must make up the exam within the next two business days, or I might not be able to allow a make-up and you would receive a zero. If you are going to make up the exam, contact the testing center immediately (www.pcc.edu/resources/testing/proctored) to learn what time you might be able to make up the exam. If you are going to miss the final exam, contact me before the test is given.
Above all else, get in contact with me if you have missed or will miss an exam. Space and time to make up an exam is limited. You need to make arrangements as soon as there is an issue.

paragraphs.title: Exam Redos
paragraphs.p: There may be opportunities to try an exam for a second, or even a third time. These opportunities will be discussed in class if and when they arise.

paragraphs.title: Accommodated Testing
paragraphs.p: Students who experience disability-related barriers should contact Disability Services: www.pcc.edu/disability. If students elect to use approved academic adjustments, they must provide, in advance, formal notification from Disability Services to the instructor. Exam accommodations may include, but are not limited to, extended time and a distraction-free environment.

introduction.p: PCC and the world at large offer several resources that you may benefit from while taking this course.

paragraphs.title: Tutoring
paragraphs.p: The Student Learning Center at Cascade offers free tutoring in math. You should find some time to check it out, if you haven't already. Details can be found at www.pcc.edu/resources/tutoring/cascade.

paragraphs.title: PCC Student Learning Center Math Self-Study Resources
paragraphs.p: Some PCC faculty have been putting together self-study material for mathematics topics, including the topics in this course. If you would like to see an alternative to what is in your textbook, please visit spot.pcc.edu/slc/mathresources/output/html/.

paragraphs.title: College Success Courses
paragraphs.p: There are several one-credit courses available to help you maximize your success in the college experience. These include courses specifically geared toward study skills. The following site offers information on these courses as well as tips for success: www.pcc.edu/resources/panther-tracks/college-success/study-skills.html.

paragraphs.title: Online Videos
paragraphs.p: At the Khan Academy (www.khanacademy.org) you can find thousands of 10- to 30-minute videos on various mathematics topics. See what you can find that may be relevant to the topics we are studying in class using appropriate search terms.
Khan Academy is just one such site. See what else you can find online searching for math videos. If you find a series of videos that you feel is helpful, keep visiting them as the term progresses.

paragraphs.title: Counseling Services
paragraphs.p: Get help with personal or career concerns that may be impacting your academic success. Trained professional counselors can also assist you with decision-making, goal-setting, and personal development.
www.pcc.edu/resources/counseling.

paragraphs.title: Multicultural Center
paragraphs.p: A welcoming and inclusive space for diverse students. One of the many services is one-on-one help for math courses, drop-in or by appointment:

paragraphs.title: Queer Resource Center
paragraphs.p: (CA SU 302)
A welcoming and safe space to hang out and be yourself. Free computer use, coffee and more:

paragraphs.title: Student Computing Center
paragraphs.p: Internet access, mathematics computer programs, and more (orientation required).
Allocation of 100 double-sided pages of free printing per term (does not roll over to next term).

paragraphs.title: Veteran's Resource Center
paragraphs.p: Relax, connect, computer workstations, work study and volunteer opportunities, and more. For additional information:

paragraphs.title: Women's Resource Center
paragraphs.p: A wide variety of services that support the academic achievement of women:

paragraphs.title: ADA Accommodation
paragraphs.p: Students who experience disability-related barriers should contact Disability Services: www.pcc.edu/disability. If students elect to use approved academic adjustments, they must provide, in advance, formal notification from Disability Services to the instructor.

paragraphs.title: Email Notice
paragraphs.p: Due to Federal laws and concerns about privacy, all email communication between instructor and student shall be done via PCC assigned email address. Access email via MyPCCsee instructor during office hours if unfamiliar with using MyPCC.

paragraphs.title: Equity & Inclusion Nondiscrimination Nonharassment (Title IX)
paragraphs.p: Portland Community College is committed to creating and fostering a learning and working environment based on open communication and mutual respect. This is an integral part of the College's academic mission to enrich our students' educational experiences and prepare them to live in and contribute to a global society. If you believe you have encountered sexual harassment, sexual misconduct, sexual assault, or discrimination based on race, color, religion, age, national origin, veteran status, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, or disability please contact the Office of Equity and Inclusion at (971) 722-5840 or equity.inclusion@pcc.edu.

paragraphs.title: Flexibility Statement
paragraphs.p: The instructor reserves the right to modify course content and/or substitute assignments and learning activities in response to institutional, weather, or class situations. Flash Alert Messenger is a free service that delivers closure information: www.pcc.edu/about/announcements/closure-information.html

paragraphs.title: Sanctuary College
paragraphs.p: PCC is a sanctuary college. See: www.pcc.edu/resources/undocumented-students

paragraphs.title: Grading and Registration Policies and Deadlines
Student Rights and Responsibilities Handbook
paragraphs.p: Students are required to comply with the Student Rights and Responsibilities Handbook. Included are policies on Students Rights, Student Conduct, Grade Appeal, Academic Integrity, Consensual Relationship Statement, and Children on PCC properties.
